awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The effects of nutritional ecology and feeding competition on growth and development
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Learning what to eat, how, and where to find food are significant challenges that arise over the course of development. Such challenges can also be social, when individuals have to compete with others for access to food. Yet how feeding competition affects food choice and developmental outcomes is poorly understood, particularly in scenarios where food is abundant and distributed evenly across an environment. This doctoral dissertation research tests how variation in feeding ecologies, including food competition, affects food choice and developmental outcomes among wild juvenile non-human primates inhabiting changing ecological and demographic environments. Results contribute to existing conservation management plans and provide concrete training opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students. Results will be disseminated widely to academic and non-academic audiences.

The proposal merges theory from nutritional ecology and life history to investigate the significance of feeding competition among developing non-human primates, who lack the foraging competence of adults. Major objectives include investigating: 1) variation in food nutritional properties along ecological gradients; 2) development of adult-like foraging competence; and 3) impacts of feeding competition on dietary development of infant and juvenile individuals. The researchers integrate novel and long-term data on food nutritional properties and feeding behavior sampled across a diversity of habitat types. They collect novel nutritional data from plant food samples as well as feeding data generated through long-term monitoring and new behavioral observations. Results inform understanding of the evolution of primate juvenile periods, by improving our understanding of how immatures are impacted by feeding competition, even in contexts where food is apparently abundant. Further, this research generates insights regarding developmental responses to changes in ecology, which are important for predicting population dynamics and associated implications for conservation efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund- Karisoke Research Center

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand the impact of local ecology and feeding competition on primate folivores, especially during the juvenile period. Unlike primates in other dietary categories, primate folivores are known to rely heavily on foliage, which is abundant, available year-round and evenly distributed in their habitats, which led to the assumption that primate folivores have less feeding competition and other dietary challenges. However, accumulating evidence suggests that primate folivores are in fact subject to more dietary challenges than previously thought, which may be especially critical for young individuals that are still investing in their physical and foraging development. We investigated this problem in the Endangered wild Virunga mountain gorillas (Gorilla beringei beringei) in Volcanoes National Park in Rwanda, a population widely regarded as the most folivorous of all ape populations and occupying diverse distinct vegetation zones. This project integrated novel and long-term ecological and behavioral data sampled across a greater diversity of habitat types within the park than studied to date, to examine the nutritional properties of foods consumed by Virunga mountain gorillas, and explore the development of their feeding behavior.

We collected samples of plant foods consumed by mountain gorillas ranging in different vegetation zones and over different seasons as well as across an altitudinal gradient within the park, and assessed them for macronutrients such as protein, fat, fiber, total non-structural carbohydrates, and energy content. Our findings revealed considerable within and between plant species variation in macronutrients across different ecological habitats of the park, which was more driven by spatial factors such as altitude rather than temporal factors. This finding contributes to recent evidence showing that primate folivores experience more ecological variation in terms of food quality. Our results of spatial nutritional variability may shed light into the variation of mountain gorilla life history and behavioral patterns reported for this population. Further, they can help inform the planned efforts by the Rwandan government to expand the park boundary in support of gorilla conservation measures. This ecological variation, which in turn may influence dietary variation, would be especially critical for immature individuals. In our investigation of the feeding development of immature Virunga mountain gorillas, our results revealed different patterns of diet composition throughout development between mountain gorillas ranging in different habitats within the park, which is suggested to relate to different foods consumed in those habitats. Further, we found age-related variation in foraging competence, with infants and juveniles being less competent compared to adults. Our results did not support the hypothesis that immatures are constrained by the time needed to learn foraging skills, though the mechanical food properties partially explained variation in foraging competence. This may suggest that young juvenile gorillas have attained sufficient foraging and processing abilities, despite their early weaning. Or, that their foods are not actually that challenging to process. Since, the acquisition of foraging competence in immatures may also be constrained by other factors including feeding competition with older individuals, we investigated whether infant and juvenile mountain gorillas experience competitive interactions especially given the cohesive social system characteristic of this population. Using long-term datasets from the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund, this project revealed that rates of competitive interactions increased with the age of immatures, and this occurred faster in a feeding context than non-feeding context. These findings complement knowledge in socioecological models, which have tended to focus exclusively on adults. But this study provides more insight about the juvenile period and indicated that immatures experience feeding competition.

This project has broader societal impacts including training, mentorship, and public outreach opportunities. This study generated novel nutritional and behavioral datasets obtained from Virunga mountain gorillas ranging in habitats that have been less studied (towards the eastern side of the park), and these data represent important resources for early career scholars as they advance in their career and address other pertinent research questions in the field of primate behavioral ecology, nutrition and conservation. Throughout the running of the project, the latter provided training opportunities to nine graduates from the University of Rwanda, who were actively involved in the field and lab related research activities. Further, two undergraduate students from the University of Rwanda and one undergraduate from the George Washington University were mentored on their senior research projects which are connected to this study, and all three mentees have successfully completed their projects. Finally, in collaboration with conservation stakeholders in Rwanda, an outreach event was organized during the project period and targeted high school students local to the field site in Rwanda, with the aim to increase knowledge of great ape biology, feeding ecology, and habitat conservation.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2023
Modified by: Axelle Kamanzi Shimwa
